Award.AwardTitle: Land Cover and hydrology - assessing controls on Si cycling in a changing Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Joanna C. Carey has been awarded an NSF EAR Postdoctoral fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, MA. Her research will examine how shifting land cover and permafrost thaw is altering silicon (Si) biogeochemistry in the Arctic. By examining ten large river systems in Alaska, this project will quantify how warming of the terrestrial landscape is altering Si availability in downstream receiving waters. Because Si availability in marine systems is critical for the survival of diatoms, the most abundant type of phytoplankton in marine waters, the results of this research will have direct implications for marine carbon dynamics. Land cover and hydrology are two important controls over Si export to marine systems, but to date these factors have yet to be examined in conjunction in Arctic ecosystems. In addition to a lack of baseline information on Arctic Si cycling, the rapid pace of warming in polar latitudes makes this work timely. The education arm of this fellowship will consist of engagement with local Alaskan communities through working with the Yukon River Inter-tribal Watershed Council and outreach with public high school Earth Science courses in Providence, RI to teach students about climate change and Arctic ecosystems. In addition, Dr. Carey will share the results of her research results with policy makers.

Although geochemical factors exert large controls over riverine Si fluxes, watershed land cover (i.e. terrestrial vegetation) has also recently been identified as another important control over riverine Si fluxes in temperate and tropical systems. However, the role of terrestrial biological processes has yet to be examined in the Arctic. Hydrologic flowpaths, including water residence time, is another critical driver of riverine Si fluxes. Both of these factors are rapidly changing in Arctic ecosystems due to recent warming, potentially impacting the magnitudes and timing of Si exports to coastal receiving waters and shifting phytoplankton species compositions. The novel use of germanium (Ge)/Si tracers will allow Dr. Carey to decipher between geochemical vs. biological drivers of Si fluxes across a gradient of vegetation and permafrost cover. Using a space-for-time substitution, this work will create the first predictive framework of how future warming will alter Si availability in marine waters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific Outcomes Overview: This project investigated how climatic warming is impacting silicon (Si) biogeochemistry in Alaskan rivers, streams, and tundra ecosystems. The objective of this proposal was determine how changes in permafrost and land cover will alter the magnitude and timing of Si exchange from terrestrial to aquatic ecosystems. To do this, I quantified dissolved and biogenic Si concentrations and fluxes in seven rivers draining a large north-south gradient of permafrost and land cover in the Yukon and Arctic North Slope basins in Alaska. This data demonstrated that future warming will increase dissolved Si exports to downstream receiving waters but leave biogenic Si exports unchanged. Moreover, due to earlier ice-out with warming, loads of total Si fluxes to downstream waters will occur sooner in the year, potentially altering the timing of the spring diatom bloom in coastal receiving waters.

 

In addition to the examination of river fluxes across large spatial scales, this project investigated the role of land cover change on Si cycling at smaller spatial scales in the upland tundra. Specifically, I examined how shrub expansion and the increasing frequency and intensity of wildfire alter rates of Si uptake by vegetation and Si release via streams in tundra ecosystems. To do this, I quantified Si concentrations and biomass in above and belowground wet sedge, tussock, and shrub tundra vegetation. I also compared this accumulation in burned and unburned plots, and related these values to stream exports from these small catchments. We found that such changes in land cover significantly increase Si uptake by land plants, but stream exports remain unchanged. Together, this data shows that warming will alter Si cycling in Arctic tundra ecosystems, but net changes in Si exchange from terrestrial to aquatic systems depends on spatial scale; at large spatial scales, fluxes of Si to coastal systems will likely increase due to permafrost thaw, but increasing retention of Si by land plants may limit this flux, especially over smaller regions.

 

Intellectual Merit:  Si cycling at the land-sea interface plays a direct role in phytoplankton species composition and carbon dynamics in marine systems because diatoms, one of the most common types of phytoplankton in marine waters, require as much Si as nitrogen on a molar basis. While lithology and runoff are important controls on Si export globally, land cover has recently been identified as another important driver of Si fluxes in temperate systems, in part due to the ability of terrestrial vegetation to sequester large amounts of Si. However, the role of land cover in controlling Si cycling in Arctic regions remained unexamined prior to this project. Understanding the controls on Si fluxes in the Arctic is important because of the rapid pace of change occurring in at high northern-latitudes (two to six times faster than global averages). Warmer temperatures are leading to permafrost degradation and shifts in land cover, with direct impacts to Si biogeochemistry along the land-ocean continuum. Moreover, because the Arctic Ocean receives a disproportionately greater degree of river inputs per unit volume compared to other oceans, it is particularly susceptible to changes in river-derived Si inputs. The lack of baseline information on Si cycling in the Arctic, combined with the rapid pace at which climate change is altering the Arctic system (i.e. permafrost thaw, shifting vegetation and wetland coverage), made this research timely and critically important.

 

Broader Impacts: Climate change is impacting every facet of the globe, but much of the public remains unaware and poorly informed about the causes and consequences of climate change. This work funded me to work with the Yukon River Inter-tribal Watershed Council to engage with local Alaskan communities, predominantly through publication in their Newsletter. In addition, I traveled to Washington D.C. to meet with legislators regarding climate change policy, and particularly how it relates to the Arctic. These visits were facilitated through the American Geophysical Union, and specifically my position on the Cryosphere Executive Committee as the Public Affairs Liaison. Finally, I worked with urban and rural community organizations to teach climate change and oceanography to middle and high school students from under-represented backgrounds in STEM fields. Through this work, I strove to educate students about climate change and foster their curiosity at the fascinating processes occurring on Earth.
